0.user_question:
Find the maximum value of
\[\frac{x - y}{x^4 + y^4 + 6}\]over all real numbers $x$ and $y.$

ost_step.1: Notice that both terms inside the fraction are always nonnegative since any even power of a real number is nonnegative. Also notice that when either variable is zero or vice versa, our expression becomes undefined. Let us analyze what happens as one approaches infinity while keeping everything else constant. As $|y|$ gets very large compared to |x|,$the numerator tends toward negative infinite whereas denominator tending towards positive infinity hence whole fraction goes to negative infinte so it cannot take any finite maxmimum . But consider x=2 ,then above equation reduces into \[\frac {x }{x^{4} +y^{4}+6 } =\frac{2}{2^{4} +y^{4}+6}]\]which clearly attains minimum not maximium thus funtion doesnot possess global maximum but local minima exists though I am unable to solve further steps required i guess calculus would come handy here.. !!!! :) Hope you get some good ideas :D ;-) Now go ahead explore your limits ;) .....and may u cross them without getting stuck anywhere....!!! Good luck !! Take care & regards Shruti. direct_answer.text: To determine the maximum value of the function \[f(x,y) = \frac{x - y}{x^4 + y^4 + 6}\] over all real numbers \(x\) and \(y\), let's first examine the properties of the function. Both the numerator (\(x - y\)) and the denominator (\(x^4 + y^4 + 6\)) consist of sums of squares plus constants. Notably, each term raised to an even power produces a non-negative outcome because squaring any real number yields a non-negative result. Consequently, neither the numerator nor the denominator ever takes on negative values independently—they fluctuate positively depending on the relationship between \(x\) and \(y\). 0.user_question:
Find the maximum value of
\[\frac{x - y}{x^4 + y^4 + 6}\]over all real numbers $x$ and $y.$

direct_answer.text:
We may assume without loss of generality that $|x|\ge |y|$, since swapping $x$ and $y$ doesn't affect our inequality; therefore, it suffices to prove \[\frac{x-y}{x^4+y^4+6}< \frac{x}{|x|^4+\left(\tfrac{|y|}{x}\right)^{4}+6},\]for each nonzero $y$. By multiplying both sides by the denominators, rearranging terms yields \[(|x|^4+y^4)(x-y)> x\left[(\tfrac{y}{x})^4+6-\tfrac{(y/x)^4}{x^4+y^4}\right].\]It remains to show \[|x|^4+y^4>\tfrac{|y|}{x}\left[\left(\tfrac{y}{x}\right)^4+6-\tfrac{1}{\tfrac{y}{x}^4+\tfrac{y^4}{x^4}}\right],\]which simplifies as follows:\begin{align*}
& \qquad |\tfrac{xy}{x}|=|y|\\ &\qquad \tfrac{y}{x}-\tfrac{xy}{x}=y

1.subquestion: Let $k = \frac{x - y}{x^4 + y^4 + 6}.$ Then multiply through by $x^4 + y^4 + 6,$ which does not equal zero since neither variable equals zero (if they did, their denominators would have been negative), to get rid of the fractional coefficient of $k$:

subanswer.text: This yields $x - y = k(x^4 + y^4 + 6)$. Rearranging terms leads to \[x - y = kx^4 + ky^4 + 6k.\] Adding 6k to both sides produces \[x + 6k = kx^4 + ky^4 + y,\] or equivalently \[\frac{x}{(k)}+\frac{6k}{(k)}=(\frac{x}{(k)})^{4}+(\frac{y}{(k)})^{4}+ (\frac{y}{k}).\]This shows that any point lying on the line defined above must satisfy our constraint as well; if such a fourth
